taxonConcepts.nameAccordingTo: Species 2000 & ITIS Catalogue of Life: April 2013

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#GeneralDescription
dataObjects.title: Biology
dataObjects.description: An opportunistic diurnal feeder, eating detritus and plant material, preying on small aquatic animals, including small fish. Very resistant to low temperatures. (Ref. 59043).  Common in creeks, rivers, swamps and lakes (Ref. 74689).  This species is an easy open spawner that lays its eggs on a stone or piece of wood (Ref. 12251). Both parents care for the eggs and fry (Ref. 12251).  Consumed locally.  Reported to reach 25.0 cm SL (Ref. 59043).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: South America:  Coastal drainages of Uruguay and Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil; Paraná River basin, lower part of Paraná River in Argentina.
dataObjects.references: Kullander, S.O. 2003 Cichlidae (Cichlids). p. 605-654. In R.E. Reis, S.O. Kullander and C.J. Ferraris, Jr. (eds.) Checklist of the Freshwater Fishes of South and Central America. Porto Alegre: EDIPUCRS, Brasil. (Ref. 36377)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Distribution
dataObjects.description: Southern South America: Argentina, Brazil, Chile (introduced) and Uruguay; also Portugal and Spain (introduced).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Morphology
dataObjects.description: Dorsal spines (total): 15 - 17; Dorsal soft rays (total): 9 - 11; Anal spines: 5 - 7; Analsoft rays: 7 - 9

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Size
dataObjects.title: Max. size
dataObjects.description: 19.3 cm SL (male/unsexed; (Ref. 56003)); max. reported age: 10 years (Ref. 40602)
references: Stawikowski, R. and U. Werner 1998 Die Buntbarsche Amerikas, Band 1. Verlag Eugen Ulmer, Stuttgart, Germany, 540 p. (Ref. 40602)
Andrade, P.M. and F.M.S. Braga 2005 Diet and feeding of fish from Grande River, located below the Volta Grande reservoir, MG-SP. Braz. J. Biol. 65(3):377-385. (Ref. 56003)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#DiagnosticDescription
dataObjects.description: This species differs from its congeners in having a lower jaw longer than upper and mouth pointing upwards; has the shortest dorsal scale cover and the least scaled dorsal and anal fins among (together with A. tembe); with four abdominal bars (present in more than 80% of individuals as compared to 50% or less in all other species (Ref. 74689).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Diseases
dataObjects.description: Procamallanus Infection 17. Parasitic infestations (protozoa, worms, etc.)

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#LifeCycle
dataObjects.description: This species is an easy open spawner that lays its eggs on a stone or piece of wood. Both parents care for the eggs and fry (Ref. 12251).  In Europe where it has invaded native drainages, spawns when temperature rises above 28-30°C.  Forms pairs during spawning and both sexes are territorial.  Females deposits eggs on exposed hard surfaces such as stones or wood. Both parent guard larvae and juveniles for 1-3 weeks (Ref. 59043).

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Threats
dataObjects.description: Not Evaluated

dataObjects.subject: http://rs.tdwg.org/ontology/voc/SPMInfoItems#Uses
dataObjects.title: Importance
dataObjects.description: fisheries: of no interest; aquarium: commercial
